title: New molecular details on trans-Neptunian objects - Inceptive Mind
NASA's Parker solar probe is 'safe' after historic closest approach to Sun - Business Standard
summary:
NASA's Parker solar probe is 'safe' after historic closest approach to Sun

Publication Date: December 24, 2023 | Source: NASA

The Parker Solar Probe has made history by becoming the first man-made object to complete a closest-ever approach to the Sun, and it's reported to be safe and operational.

  • The probe came within 3.8 million miles of the Sun's surface on December 24, 2023.
  • It transmitted a beacon tone indicating good health after the record-breaking approach.
  • The mission aims to uncover secrets about solar heat and solar wind.
  • The spacecraft is traveling at a speed of 430,000 mph and withstood temperatures up to 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit.
  • It has completed 21 passes of the Sun since its launch in 2018.
“This close-up study of the Sun allows Parker Solar Probe to take measurements that help scientists better understand how material in this region gets heated to millions of degrees...” - NASA

The detailed telemetry data on the probe's condition is expected on January 1, 2024.
newTitle: NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Historic Approach to the Sun

title: Four eclipses in 2025 but only one will be visible in India Ujjain observatory - The Week
summary:
Four Eclipses in 2025: Only One Visible from India

Date: December 27, 2023 Source: PTI

The year 2025 will feature two solar and two lunar eclipses, but only one will be visible from India, according to the Ujjain-based Jiwaji Observatory.

  • A total lunar eclipse on March 14 will not be visible in India as it occurs during the daytime here.
  • A partial solar eclipse on March 29 will also be missed by Indian observers.
  • The full lunar eclipse on September 7-8 will be visible in India and other regions.
  • The last eclipse of the year is a partial solar eclipse on September 21-22, which won't be visible in India.
“Indian astronomy lovers can be excited by the fact that the full lunar eclipse occurring between September 7 and 8 will be visible in the country.” - Dr. Rajendra Prakash Gupt

In summary, despite multiple eclipses in 2025, only one will allow viewers in India to witness the celestial phenomenon.
newTitle: Four Eclipses in 2025: Only One Visible from India

title: Great magnetic drift: North Pole’s journey to Siberia - Telangana Today
summary:
Great Magnetic Drift: North Pole’s Journey to Siberia

Published Date: 27 December 2024, Source: Telangana Today

The magnetic North Pole is moving towards Russia at an unpredictable pace, causing concern among scientists due to its implications on global navigation systems.

  • The magnetic North Pole shifts due to convection currents in Earth’s outer core.
  • Recent movements have slowed from 55 km per year to 25 km per year.
  • This shift disrupts the World Magnetic Model (WMM) used in GPS and military navigation.
  • The movement may signal potential future magnetic pole reversals.
  • Robust monitoring is necessary to prepare for possible disruptions.
“This ongoing polar odyssey underscores the importance of vigilance in an ever-changing world.”

The shift of the magnetic North Pole toward Siberia raises alarm among scientists and highlights the importance of continued research and monitoring of Earth’s magnetic field.
newTitle: Great Magnetic Drift: North Pole’s Journey to Siberia

NASA's Parker solar probe makes a historic Sun encounter as fastest man-made object ever: Explained in 10 - The Economic Times
summary:
NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Historic Approach to the Sun

Publication Date: December 24, 2023
Source: Economic Times

The Parker Solar Probe has successfully made its closest-ever approach to the Sun, coming within 3.86 million miles, setting a record for human-made objects.

  • The spacecraft is about the size of a small car and was launched in 2018.
  • This closest approach took place on December 24, 2023, within the solar corona.
  • The probe is designed to gather data about the Sun's outer atmosphere and solar wind.
  • Parker Solar Probe will endure extreme temperatures and speeds, moving at 430,000 mph.
  • It aims to solve mysteries regarding solar wind and the temperature of the corona.
“No human-made object has ever passed this close to a star, so Parker will truly be returning data from uncharted territory.” - Nick Pinkine, Mission Operations Manager

This monumental achievement marks a significant milestone in solar research, potentially leading to new insights into solar phenomena.
newTitle: NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Historic Approach to the Sun

title: NASA warns! Two airplane-sized asteroids to pass close to Earth tomorrow – here’s what you need to know - The Times of India
summary:
NASA warns! Two airplane-sized asteroids to pass close to Earth tomorrow – here’s what you need to know

Publication Date: December 27, 2024

Source: Times of India

In late December 2024, NASA has confirmed that two asteroids, 2024 YC1 and 2024 YQ2, will pass safely close to Earth, occurring at a distance well beyond the danger zone. Despite being a cause for attention, both pose no risk of collision.

  • Asteroid 2024 YC1 is approximately 170 feet long and will pass Earth at 639,000 miles away, moving at 20,666 miles per hour.
  • Asteroid 2024 YQ2 is smaller, at around 80 feet, and will pass Earth at a slightly higher speed of 23,313 miles per hour.
  • Nasa's monitoring of asteroids is critical for planetary defense and understanding solar system formation.
  • Ongoing observation and study of NEOs (Near-Earth Objects) help prepare for potential future threats.
  • The impacts of past asteroids have had devastating effects on Earth, emphasizing the need for continuous monitoring.
“One such impact is said to have caused the extinction of dinosaurs about 66 million years ago.”

The close approaches of 2024 YC1 and 2024 YQ2 reiterate the importance of asteroid monitoring as part of NASA's planetary defense strategy.
newTitle: NASA warns! Two airplane-sized asteroids to pass close to Earth tomorrow – here’s what you need to know

title: SpaceX Missions List 2025: From Starship Flight 7 Launch to Crew-10 Mission, Here’s Brief on Major - LatestLY
Brunhes–Matuyama Reversal: When Earth's Magnetic Field Flips - IFLScience
summary:
Brunhes–Matuyama Reversal: When Earth's Magnetic Field Flips

Published: 15 hours ago Source: IFL Science

The Earth's magnetic field can flip over long timescales, such as during the Brunhes–Matuyama reversal, which happened about 780,000 years ago. The poles can move anywhere from 10,000 years to over 50 million years apart, with the last true reversal being a subject of scientific research.

  • The Earth's magnetic field is not static and has been recorded to weaken over time.
  • Temporary reversal events have been documented, such as the Laschamp event 41,000 years ago.
  • Reversal events have significant geological implications, influencing magnetic pole positions and climate.
  • Neanderthal extinction and megafauna extinction events have been hypothesized to relate to magnetic shifts, but evidence remains inconclusive.
“The field geometry of reversed polarity lasted for only about 440 years, and it was associated with a field strength that was only one quarter of today's field.” - Norbert Nowaczyk, GFZ German Research Centre for Geosciences.

Understanding these magnetic changes is important as they may continue to influence life on Earth, and current predictions about the mobility of the magnetic poles indicate ongoing shifts that could lead to future reversals.
newTitle: Brunhes–Matuyama Reversal: When Earth's Magnetic Field Flips

title: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe Reports Successful Closest Approach to Sun - NASA Blogs
summary:
NASA’s Parker Solar Probe Reports Successful Closest Approach to Sun

Date: December 26, 2024   |   Source: Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory

The Parker Solar Probe successfully made its closest approach to the Sun, transmitting a beacon signal back to Earth indicating its operational status.

  • The probe passed approximately 3.8 million miles from the solar surface at speeds nearing 430,000 miles per hour on December 24.
  • A signal was received by the mission operations team shortly before midnight EST on December 26.
  • Upcoming telemetry data is expected to provide further insights on January 1.
  • The mission aims to better understand the heating of solar materials and the origins of solar wind.
  • Part of NASA’s Living With a Star program, the probe's mission continues to contribute to solar science.
“This close-up study of the Sun allows Parker Solar Probe to take measurements that help scientists better understand how material in this region gets heated to millions of degrees.”

This successful approach reinforces the importance of the Parker Solar Probe in understanding solar phenomena critical to life on Earth.
newTitle: NASA’s Parker Solar Probe Reports Successful Closest Approach to Sun

title: 6 Black hole images at the center of galaxy captured by NASA - India.com
summary:
6 Black hole images at the center of galaxy captured by NASA

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: India.com

This article discusses the impressive images of black holes captured by NASA, highlighting the technological collaboration involved in this monumental achievement.

  • A black hole is defined as a dense object with an extreme gravitational pull.
  • Images were obtained using a global network of eight radio telescopes, functioning as an Earth-sized telescope.
  • The first image of a supermassive black hole was obtained in 2019 from the M87 galaxy.
  • In 2022, the first image of Sagittarius A*, the black hole at the Milky Way's center, was released.
  • The M87 black hole is approximately 6.5 billion times the mass of the Sun, while Sagittarius A* is about 4 million times the mass of the Sun.
  • The captured images illustrate the black hole located about 55 million light-years away from Earth.
“Thanks For Reading! Next: 7 stunning images of deep space shared by NASA.”

This accomplishment marks a significant milestone in astrophysics, deepening our understanding of black holes and space.
newTitle: 6 Black hole images at the center of galaxy captured by NASA

summary:
What to look for in the sky? NASA’s guide for amateur space lovers

Publication Date: December 3, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

This article serves as a guide for amateur space enthusiasts, highlighting various celestial events and objects that can be observed in the sky. It emphasizes the diversity of phenomena and offers tips on what to look for when stargazing.

  • Residents can observe five planets without a telescope: Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn.
  • The Moon goes through phases each month, offering different sights from waxing to waning.
  • Meteor showers occur annually as the Earth passes through debris trails.
  • Comets come from the cold depths of the outer solar system and can be stunning to watch.
  • Eclipses, both solar and lunar, provide spectacular views when properly timed.
“Space is full of amazing things to see.”

This guide empowers space lovers to make the most of their stargazing experiences, turning them into informed observers of the night sky.

title: The unbearable slowness of being: “Streaming a high-def vide... - kottke.org
Understanding Mars Helicopter Ingenuity’s Last Flight On Mars - Astrobiology News
summary:
Understanding Mars Helicopter Ingenuity's Last Flight On Mars

Publication Date: December 12, 2024

Source: Astrobiology

This article reviews the final flight of NASA’s Ingenuity Mars Helicopter, which marked a significant achievement as the first aircraft to fly on another planet. An in-depth assessment indicates that issues with Ingenuity’s navigation system contributed to the mission's end on January 18, 2024.

  • Ingenuity performed 72 flights over nearly three years and flew significantly farther than initially planned.
  • The final flight, designed for a brief vertical hop, ended with severe damage to the helicopter's rotor blades.
  • An investigation suggests that a lack of surface features caused navigation errors, leading to a hard landing.
  • Despite being grounded, Ingenuity continues to transmit weather and avionics data useful for future missions.
“Ingenuity has given us the confidence and data to envision the future of flight at Mars.” – Teddy Tzanetos, project manager

The findings from this investigation are expected to inform future Mars helicopter designs and operations, demonstrating the long-term impact of Ingenuity's mission.
newTitle: Understanding Mars Helicopter Ingenuity's Last Flight On Mars

title: Asteroid Vesta found to have channels that look like water-made gullies - Earth.com
summary:
Asteroid Vesta found to have channels that look like water-made gullies

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Earth.com

The discovery of channels resembling water-made gullies on asteroid Vesta challenges existing assumptions about liquid presence in airless conditions.

  • NASA's Dawn spacecraft found deep channels that resemble liquid flow formations.
  • Scientists hypothesize that hidden ice below the surface could be responsible for these channels.
  • Lab experiments suggest saline solutions may persist long enough to form the observed channels.
  • Impacts on Vesta could release liquid water, potentially leading to the formation of surface features.
“Not only do impacts trigger a flow of liquid on the surface, the liquids are active long enough to create specific surface features.” - Jennifer Scully, NASA

This finding opens possibilities for understanding the distribution of water in the solar system, hinting at hidden moisture in other celestial bodies.

summary:
New Discovery Explains How Gold Forms in Earth's Volcanic Zones!

Published: 2024, Source: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

A breakthrough discovery by an international team highlights the role of a unique gold-sulfur complex in gold deposit formation beneath Earth's volcanic areas.

The study reveals the conditions under which gold is transported from the Earth's mantle to the surface, particularly in subduction zones around the Pacific Ring of Fire.

  • Gold-trisulfur complex forms under specific conditions in the mantle.
  • Subduction zones are rich in gold deposits due to volcanic activity.
  • The research validates earlier theories about gold-sulfur interactions.
“This complex plays a significant role in the enrichment of gold in magma that travels to the surface.” - Adam Simon, Professor at the University of Michigan

This discovery provides vital insights into geological processes and has implications for gold mining and exploration.

Marine heatwave decimates nearly 4 million of Alaska’s common murre seabirds - Down To Earth Magazine
summary:
Marine Heatwave Decimates Nearly 4 Million of Alaska’s Common Murre Seabirds

Published on: 26 Dec 2024, 3:24 pm

An extreme marine heatwave linked to climate change has devastated Alaska’s common murre population, resulting in the death of nearly four million seabirds over three years. This is the largest documented wildlife mortality event in modern history.

  • The murre population in 13 monitored colonies plummeted by 52-78% between 2014 and 2016.
  • Approximately 1.28 million murres died at the monitored colonies, with an extrapolated total loss of around four million across all known colonies.
  • About half to three-quarters of the common murres have not returned to their colonies seven years post-heatwave.
  • The decline in murres is linked to a sudden drop in the quality, quantity, and accessibility of their food sources, leading to mass starvation.
  • The heatwave also impacted other species like Pacific cod and humpback whales, indicating broader ecological consequences.
“To our knowledge, this is the largest mortality event of any wildlife species reported during the modern era,” the researchers concluded.

The study serves as a grim reminder of the severe impact of climate change on marine ecosystems, emphasizing the need for urgent conservation efforts.
newTitle: Marine Heatwave Causes Dramatic Decline in Alaska’s Common Murre Population
